content:
ASIA-PAC

US-China trade deal agreement will be reached in the 3rd-4th week of May, according to Chinese diplomatic sources. (Newswires)

Chinese Finance Ministry said February YTD state-owned firm's profits rose 10.0% and liabilities rose 8.1% YY. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK Parliament are to vote on 3 Amendments tonight:

(A)   LETWIN: Seeks to change the rules of parliament on March 27 in order to provide time for lawmakers to debate and hold indicative votes. It has been signed by more than 120 lawmakers. The result of any such indicative votes would not be binding on the government but if it showed a majority for an alternative Brexit path. A similar amendment voted on earlier this month lost by two votes, this is therefore expected to have a good chance of passing.

(D)   LABOUR: Calls on the government to provide parliamentary time for lawmakers to find a majority for a different approach on Brexit.

(F)  BECKETT: This amendment states that if the UK comes within seven calendar days of leaving the EU without a deal, the government must ask parliament whether it would approve a no deal exit or if it should seek a further delay to Brexit.

Note: Letwin amendment (A) will be whipped against tonight by the government, while Labour leader Corbyn said it will be supporting the amendment although a Labour source later suggested doubts the amendment (A) on indicative votes will pass.

UK PM May said there is no support to hold a Meaningful Vote 3 but will continue to have discussions with lawmakers to bring forth a vote this week, while she also stated that she will provide government time for a series of indicative votes on Brexit but will not pledge to implement any outcome of the votes. Furthermore, UK PM May spokesman said the government will only hold another meaningful vote if there is prospect of success and that the government understands there is no necessity to have a Brexit vote before March 29th after the EU summit. (Newswires)

BBC's Laura Kuenssberg reports that some Remain tending government ministers want to vote for the Letwin amendment tonight and might quit if No 10 tries to stop them. (Newswires)

German Ifo Business Climate New (Mar) 99.6 vs. Exp. 98.5 (Prev. 98.5, Rev. 98.7). (Newswires) 

US

Fed's Harker (non-voter, dove) said economic risks tilt very slightly to the downside although the outlook is pretty good, while he added that he is in wait and see mode and that he favours one hike this year and one in 2020 at most. (Newswures)

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said the Fed should focus on actual inflation, inflation expectations, and real wage growth (net of productivity) to determine if the economy is running above or below potential. (Newswires)

Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said she had a good meeting with USTR Lighthizer in Washington in which they discussed metals tariffs and the new continental trade pact. (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) hosted its Showtime event today, where it unveiled its expected streaming service, still with no price indication, which will included Amazon (AMZN) Prime content. Apple also unveiled: a new gaming service Apple Arcade, weighing on competitors (ATVI, EA); a new payment service “Apple Card” in collaboration with Goldman (GS) and Mastercard (MA); Apple News service for USD 9.99/month. Viacom (VIAB) and Discovery (DISCA) surged on Monday’s open after Viacom came to a licensing agreement with AT&T (T) for airing its channels. Biogen (BIIB) opened higher on the announcement of a USD 5bln share repurchase programme. Consumer discretionary had a leading day, with retailers (M, KSS, CAG, FL, JWN) leading, Deutsche Bank research notes it as its 10th best day vs. the market in the past year. Akamai (AKAM) nosedived on a downgrade at Deutsche Bank, Analog Devices (ADI) and Texas Instruments (TXN) also suffered from downgrades at Bernstein. TechnipFMC (FTI) traded higher after receiving a large contract in Indonesia from Eni. Boeing (BA) drifted higher in the midst of it arranging a presentation for its new safety and software updates, also Cowen mentioned it positively. Chipmakers were an underperforming sector today wit the likes of Nvidia (NVDA), Micron (MU) and Intel (INTC) all lower. Phillip Morris (PM) opened in the red after cutting its FY EPS guidance lower as one of its Canadian subsidiaries enters bankruptcy filing. Tesla (TSLA) underperformed on the back of an NYT report of data showing a slowdown of new Tesla vehicles on roads as well as RBC cutting its price target on the Co. SPX -0.08% at 2798, NDX -0.12% at 7317, DJI +0.06%.

The Treasury complex saw another bout of bull-flattening, with the 3m/10yr spread inverting further to -7bps at one point in US trade, which put the equity complex on the defensive (analysts at Nomura have suggested this could explain some of the price action late on Friday); during that episode, 10-year yields also fell below the effective Fed Funds Rate (at 2.41%), and markets were pricing around a 75% chance that the Fed would CUT rates this year (it was 25% before the FOMC meeting last week). Today's moves - like Friday's - are being attributed to the FOMC dovishness, which is likely to be echoed in Fedspeak through the course of the week. There has been heightened attention on its implications, and specifically, what it portends for the future performance of the US economy, given that the 3m/10y part of the curve inverted aead of recessions in 2007/09, 2001, and the 1990/1 recession; it also inverted in 1998 slightly, and at the end of 1995 though the economy continued to grow. Traders have been passing around the SF Fed's analysis on yield curve spreads, penned last August, which concluded that "the traditional 10y–3m spread is the most reliable predictor (of recession), and we do not find any evidence that would support discarding this long-standing benchmark as a measure of the shape of the yield curve. It is worth emphasizing again, however, that all of these term spreads are fairly accurate predictors and quite informative about future recession risk." The SF followed-up with an analysis in February, where it said the shape of the curve was "worrisome," but concluded then that it needed to see a clear inversion of the curve, and it was too early to predict a recession then. SocGen's strategists think that we will see a US recession in 2020, in what it describes as "a hangover that will follow the excesses of the fiscal package and the damage done by US trade policy." But that view is not consensus; ING does not see a US recession either this year or next given the still solid US economy. "Rather, we view the trend of global curve flattening as natural at the current stage of the cycle, in line with a gradual economic slowdown rather than pencilling an imminent recession". US T-note futures (M9) settled 9+ ticks higher at 124-10+.

US MARKET WRAP 25 March 2019: 3-month/10-year inversion hits 7bp; May pulls MV3

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities flat/down, dollar down, treasuries up, crude mixed.

* REAR VIEW: Fed’s Evans; ECB’s Hansson and Rehn; PM May pulls MV3, for now; Apple Showcase; yield curve inversion continues

* AHEAD: RBA asst gov Ellis; BOJ Summary of opinions, BOJ core CPI; NZ trade; Fed voter Rosengren, Evans; Germany GFK; BOE's Broadbent; German 2yr auction, BRL IPCA inflation; US building permits, housing starts FHFA HPI, CS HPI; US consumer confidence; BCB minutes; NBH rate decision; Mex retail sales, RBNZ rate decision, energy inventories, RBA asst gov Kent.

 

* FED: Fed's Evans (voter, dove) says US economy is in a strong position and that it is a good time to pause and be cautious, added monetary policy was currently neither accommodative or restrictive. He said risks to the downside are larger than those to the upside, and rates would have to be on hold or cut if the data disappointed. Evans wants to see more inflation and does not expect a rate hike till H2 2020, but said he would act if inflation undershoots. Evans said the recent US data has been softer than expected. On the yield curve, Evans said the Fed has to be nervous when curve gets flat, though the current inversion is pretty narrow.

* ECB: ECB's Hansson (Hawk) says that the Euro-area slowdown may continue in the medium term. ECB's Rehn, a contender to replace Draghi as President when he steps down later this year, said ECB "must be worried about the economy" due to the slowdown in growth, adding Brexit was a substantial risk for the Euro area.

* BREXIT: House Speaker John Bercow selected the Letwin (A), Labour (D) and Beckett (F) amendments ahead of parliaments vote on them on Monday evening at 22:00GMT/18:00EDT. The Letwin amendment, which seeks to change the rules of parliament on March 27 in order to provide time for lawmakers to debate and hold indicative votes, appears to be gaining the most traction, with a similar vote having lost by just two votes previously this month; the government has said it will whip MPs to vote against the amendment, whilst opposition Labour has said it will vote in favour. However, heading into the evening in London, journalist reports indicated that the amendment was lining up to be rejected, where it had previously been expected to pass. Tuesday is marked down as a potential date for a third meaningful vote by PM May, although May has withdrawn the vote as it stands saying that the vote will only be held if enough parliamentary support is evident; the government said it recognises there is no necessity to have the vote before March 29th, which will be after the EU summit.

* WTI (K9) SETTLED USD 0.22 LOWER AT USD 58.82/BBL; BRENT (K9) SETTLED USD 0.18 HIGHER AT USD 67.21/BBL. Oil prices traded rather choppy to kick off the week, with WTI little changed on settlement amidst a combination of bullish and bearish talking points. The latest calculation showed Chinese imports of US crude falling 91% in February to approximately 22k BPD, compared to the prior year, highlighting the cut-off in demand from China for US crude. The market also remains cognizant of weak PMIs released Friday, despite a decent Ifo survey out of Germany today, which showed the first increase in six months. In supply news flow: South Korea and the US are to discuss extensions of Iranian sanction waivers this week; Exxon Baytown Texas refinery (584k BPD) plans to restart its large crude unit this week. Elsewhere, Positioning data of the week till March 19th showed hedge funds buying an additional 65mln bbls of oil futures and options, with net buyers of WTI, Brent and US gasoline, a firm bullish indication; this one week increase in net longs is the largest since the end of August 2018.

* SPX -0.08% at 2798, NDX -0.12% at 7317, DJI +0.06% at 25517. SECTORS: Energy -0.01%, Materials -0.16%, Industrials +0.25%, Cons Discretionary +0.56%, Cons Staples -0.01%, Healthcare -0.07%, Financials -0.40%, Tech -0.40%, Telecoms -0.19%, Utilities +0.12%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) hosted its Showtime event today, where it unveiled its expected streaming service, still with no price indication, which will included Amazon (AMZN) Prime content. Apple also unveiled: a new gaming service Apple Arcade, weighing on competitors (ATVI, EA); a new payment service “Apple Card” in collaboration with Goldman (GS) and Mastercard (MA); Apple News service for USD 9.99/month. Viacom (VIAB) and Discovery (DISCA) surged on Monday’s open after Viacom came to a licensing agreement with AT&T (T) for airing its channels. Biogen (BIIB) opened higher on the announcement of a USD 5bln share repurchase programme. Consumer discretionary had a leading day, with retailers (M, KSS, CAG, FL, JWN) leading, Deutsche Bank research notes it as its 10th best day vs. the market in the past year. Akamai (AKAM) nosedived on a downgrade at Deutsche Bank, Analog Devices (ADI) and Texas Instruments (TXN) also suffered from downgrades at Bernstein. TechnipFMC (FTI) traded higher after receiving a large contract in Indonesia from Eni. Boeing (BA) drifted higher in the midst of it arranging a presentation for its new safety and software updates, also Cowen mentioned it positively. Chipmakers were an underperforming sector today wit the likes of Nvidia (NVDA), Micron (MU) and Intel (INTC) all lower. Phillip Morris (PM) opened in the red after cutting its FY EPS guidance lower as one of its Canadian subsidiaries enters bankruptcy filing. Tesla (TSLA) underperformed on the back of an NYT report of data showing a slowdown of new Tesla vehicles on roads as well as RBC cutting its price target on the co.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 9+ TICKS HIGHER AT 124-10+. The Treasury complex saw another bout of bull-flattening, with the 3m/10yr spread inverting further to -7bps at one point in US trade, which put the equity complex on the defensive (analysts at Nomura have suggested this could explain some of the price action late on Friday); during that episode, 10-year yields also fell below the effective Fed Funds Rate (at 2.41%), and markets were pricing around a 75% chance that the Fed would CUT rates this year (it was 25% before the FOMC meeting last week). Today's moves - like Friday's - are being attributed to the FOMC dovishness, which is likely to be echoed in Fedspeak through the course of the week. There has been heightened attention on its implications, and specifically, what it portends for the future performance of the US economy, given that the 3m/10y part of the curve inverted aead of recessions in 2007/09, 2001, and the 1990/1 recession; it also inverted in 1998 slightly, and at the end of 1995 though the economy continued to grow. Traders have been passing around the SF Fed's analysis on yield curve spreads, penned last August, which concluded that "the traditional 10y–3m spread is the most reliable predictor (of recession), and we do not find any evidence that would support discarding this long-standing benchmark as a measure of the shape of the yield curve. It is worth emphasizing again, however, that all of these term spreads are fairly accurate predictors and quite informative about future recession risk." The SF followed-up with an analysis in February, where it said the shape of the curve was "worrisome," but concluded then that it needed to see a clear inversion of the curve, and it was too early to predict a recession then. SocGen's strategists think that we will see a US recession in 2020, in what it describes as "a hangover that will follow the excesses of the fiscal package and the damage done by US trade policy." But that view is not consensus; ING does not see a US recession either this year or next given the still solid US economy. "Rather, we view the trend of global curve flattening as natural at the current stage of the cycle, in line with a gradual economic slowdown rather than pencilling an imminent recession."

* 2-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 131bln in 2yr (USD 40bln Tue), 5yr (USD 41bln, Wed), 7yr USD 32bln, Thu), and an FRN (USD 18bln, Wed). USD  71.5bln matured at the month-end settlement, implying the Treasury will raise a net USD 59.5bln in new supply. USD 22.4bln of Fed holdings mature at the month-end settlement, and the Fed will add-on USD 7.9bln to 2yr, USD 8.1bln to 5yr, and USD 6.3bln to 7yr. Last week's FOMC meeting was more dovish than anticipated, with the Fed announcing that it will slow the balance sheet run-off in May, ending in September, and reducing caps on monthly redemptions to USD 15bln, from USD 30bln; it will also be reinvesting MBS coupons back into Treasuries. "With runoff ending in September, we think that Treasury will likely cut coupon auction sizes later this year (potentially focused in the 2-3y sector). Runoff ending in September will decrease Treasury issuance by about $100bn compared with runoff continuing throughout the year," TD Securities says. "The Fed will have to reinvest MBS paydowns in the open market starting in October. Starting in Q4 2020, we look for the Fed to purchase additional Treasuries in the open market to offset the growth in currency in circulation." The last auction saw demand ease a touch, though the auction saw a second consecutive stop through the screens. "Four of the last five auctions have stopped through underscoring the recent strength in performance," Barclays writes, "after the December auction tailed amid elevated market volatility and balance sheet pressures toward the end of 2018." Indirect takedown fell at the last auction, however, likely on the back of the decline in domestic investor takedown, while foreign investors have been steadily taking down less over the last four auctions. Some desks also argue that with BCN ending later this year, as well as the potential for the Treasury to cut sizes in the 2-3yr sectors, 2s might begin to trade between against OIS. Looking ahead, Barclays says that "at a current yields, the WI issue is a potential CTD in TUM9, assuming a 2.375% coupon. However, yields are at the cusp of a coupon shift. If yields decline and the coupon shifts to 2.25%, a seasoned 7y note (2.25s of Mar 21s) will be reopened. Six auction averages: High-yield 2.711%, cover 2.52x, tail 0.2bps; dealers  39.6%, directs 14.7%, indirects 45.7%.

* FX WRAP: The FX landscape certainly hints at risk-on (the 'risk-on' currencies are AUD and NZD, EMFX is up, USD is soft). However, that backdrop doesn't seem consistent with other asset classes. Equities, for instance, has seen some very choppy trade, though has been contained by key moving averages/VWAP levels, crude is mixed, and Treasuries have bull-flattened further. In fact, it was telling that as the short-end of the curve saw yields drop, USDJPY remained quite stable. The risk environment will no doubt be tested more forcefully over the course of the week, with a huge amount of Fedspeak, supply, ongoing trade talks, and the ominous inversion of the yield curve.

* JPY: The yen gained on risk aversion; overnight, risk assets took their cues from Friday's late sell-off in risk assets in the US. In early trade, the pair was magnetic to the 110.00 area, where chunky option expiries rolled-off at the NY ct; but the pair continued to linger around that area as US trade progressed. Some were also surprised that US short-end yields gyrated so aggressively, though USDJPY remained stable in afternoon trade. Overnight, BoJ Governor Kuroda said that during a future policy exit, BoJ earnings will decline, but yields should also rise which will raise BoJ bond earnings. The governor added that even if long-term rates were to increase in the future, reflecting economic improvement, pace of any increase will be gradual. BOJ Board Member Harada. BoJ's Harada said that the biggest contribution to Japan's economy from QQE was to boost productivity, and without it the jobless rate would not have fallen below 2.5%. Coming up in the Asia session, the BOJ will release its latest Summary of Opinions; it held rates at the March meeting, UBS' economists think the path to policy normalisation is becoming clearer, arguing that a slew of important signals between now and the April meeting, including the April Tankan survey, will be crucial for board members in evaluating the outlook.

* EUR: Germany's Ifo survey beat to the upside, and offered some relief after dreadful PMI data on Friday. the Ifo was driven by the expectations component rising to a three-month high. The details, however, chime with the PMI data, Pantheon Macroeconomics said: "the headline manufacturing sentiment index slid further, while confidence in services, construction and wholesale trade rose," adding that "overall, the IFO continues to signal a further slowdown in GDP growth in Q1, but the headlines confirm the story that manufacturing is in the grips of a recession, while the rest of the economy is stabilising, or even improving slightly, towards the end of Q1.

* RISK-ON FX: Even when risk sentiment was soft in the early part of the session, the Antipodes NZD, AUD (and particularly AUDJPY) traded firm, threatening a positive turnaround in the risk backdrop. For the former, RBNZ is the focus on Wednesday, while for the latter, RBA speak over the next few days (both asst governors Kent and Ellis). Nevertheless, given that risk sentiment is fragile, there could be only limited upside - especially with the RBA expected to dovish pivot in 2019.

* TRY: On the weekend, Turkish President Erdogan said that TRY sellers will pay "a very heavy price" following the 5% slide on Friday. However, the currency could face further pressure in the weeks ahead, Nordea argues, and offers seven reasons why. 1) Turkey is in a recession, and high rates have lead to a credit crunch. 2) There are risks that the CBRT could EASE policy now that inflation is coming in. 3) Geopolitical risks linger ahead of the 31 March local elections (Erdogan warned Trump about Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights, seeing the TRY weaken). 4) USD is still strong, and given Turkey's high USD funding, could make it expensive to service this debt. 5) FX reserves fell in March beneath the IMF's recommendations, limited the CBRT's ability to intervene in FX. 6) German PMIs have signalled challenges ahead, which could weigh on demand for Turkish exports. 7) The recent inversion of the Treasury curve 3m/10y could contribute further to risk-off.

* MXN: The Mexican IGAE economic activity indicator printed 1.3% YY, driven by services activity, beating the consensus 1.1%, and up from the 0.0% in December. The data offers some hope that there may be light for the Mexican economy, following the domestic and international challenges seen in Q4. Most of the drag on growth stems from the oil industry, which offset resilience in services, construction and manufacturing. Pantheon Macroeconomics thinks that the Mex economy will continue to expand at a healthy clip, citing market-friendly policies from the new Administration, which could help stabilise capex. Strength in the US economy may also offer support.

The governor added that even if long-term rates were to increase in the future, reflecting economic improvement, pace of any increase will be gradual. BOJ Board Member Harada. BoJ's Harada said that the biggest contribution to Japan's economy from QQE was to boost productivity, and without it the jobless rate would not have fallen below 2.5%. Coming up in the Asia session, the BOJ will release its latest Summary of Opinions; it held rates at the March meeting, UBS' economists think the path to policy normalisation is becoming clearer, arguing that a slew of important signals between now and the April meeting, including the April Tankan survey, will be crucial for board members in evaluating the outlook.

* EUR: Germany's Ifo survey beat to the upside, and offered some relief after dreadful PMI data on Friday. the Ifo was driven by the expectations component rising to a three-month high. The details, however, chime with the PMI data, Pantheon Macroeconomics said: "the headline manufacturing sentiment index slid further, while confidence in services, construction and wholesale trade rose," adding that "overall, the IFO continues to signal a further slowdown in GDP growth in Q1, but the headlines confirm the story that manufacturing is in the grips of a recession, while the rest of the economy is stabilising, or even improving slightly, towards the end of Q1.

* RISK-ON FX: Even when risk sentiment was soft in the early part of the session, the Antipodes NZD, AUD (and particularly AUDJPY) traded firm, threateneing a positive turnaround in the risk backdrop. For the former, RBNZ is the focus on Wednesday, while for the latter, RBA speak over the next few days (both asst governors Kent and Ellis). Nevertheless, given that risk sentiment is fragile, there could be only limited upside - especially with the RBA expected to dovish pivot in 2019.

* TRY: On the weekend, Turkish President Erdogan said that TRY sellers will pay "a very heavy price" following the 5% slide on Friday. However, the currency could face further pressure in the weeks ahead, Nordea argues, and offers seven reasons why. 1) Turkey is in a recession, and high rates have lead to a credit crunch. 2) There are risks that the CBRT could EASE policy now that inflation is coming in. 3) Geopolitical risks linger ahead of the 31 March local elections (Erdogan warned Trump about Israeli sovereignty over the Golan Heights, seeing the TRY weaken). 4) USD is still strong, and given Turkey's high USD funding, could make it expensive to service this debt. 5) FX reserves fell in March beneath the IMF's recommendations, limited the CBRT's ability to intervene in FX. 6) German PMIs have signalled challenges ahead, which could weigh on demand for Turkish exports. 7) The recent inversion of the Treasury curve 3m/10y could contribute further to risk-off.

* MXN: The Mexican IGAE economic activity indicator printed 1.3% YY, driven by services activity, beating the consensus 1.1%, and up from the 0.0% in December. The data offers some hope that there may be light for the Mexican economy, following the domestic and international challenges seen in Q4. Most of the drag on growth stems from the oil industyr, which offset resilience in services, construction and manufacturing. Pantheon Macroeconomics thinks that the Mex economy will continue to expand at a healthy clip, citing market-friendly policies from the new Administration, which could help stabilise capex. Strength in the US economy may also offer support.

subject: US T-Note Futures (M9) settle 9+ ticks higher at 124-10+
analysis_details: The Treasury complex saw another bout of bull-flattening, with the 3m/10yr spread inverting further to -7bps at one point in US trade, which put the equity complex on the defensive (analysts at Nomura have suggested this could explain some of the price action late on Friday); during that episode, 10-year yields also fell below the effective Fed Funds Rate (at 2.41%), and markets were pricing around a 75% chance that the Fed would CUT rates this year (it was 25% before the FOMC meeting last week). Today's moves - like Friday's - are being attributedto the FOMC dovishness, which is likely to be echoed in Fedspeak through the course of the week. There has been heightened attention on its implications, and specifically, what it portends for the future performance of the US economy, given that the 3m/10y part of the curve inverted aead of recessions in 2007/09, 2001, and the 1990/1 recession; it also inverted in 1998 slightly, and at the end of 1995 though the economy continued to grow. Traders have been passing around the SF Fed's analysis on yield curve spreads, penned last August, which concluded that "the traditional 10y–3m spread is the most reliable predictor (of recession), and we do not find any evidence that would support discarding this long-standing benchmark as a measure of the shape of the yield curve. It is worth emphasizing again, however, that all of these term spreads are fairly accurate predictors and quite informative about future recession risk." The SF followd-up with an analysis in February, where it said the shape of the curve was "worrisome," but concluded then that it needed to see a clear inversion of the curve, and it was too early to predict a recession then. SocGen's strategists think that we will see a US recession in 2020, in what it descrives as "a hangover that will follow the excesses of the fiscal package and the damage done by US trade policy." But that view is not consensus; ING does not see a US recession either this year or next given the still solid US economy. "Rather, we view the trend of global curve flattening as natural at the current stage of the cycle, in line with a gradual economic slowdown rather than pencilling an imminent recession."

subject: FX ANALYSIS: FX complex screams 'risk-on', belies macro 'risk-off' backdrop (JPY, EUR, AUD, NZD, TRY, MXN)
analysis_details:

Equities, for instance, has seen some very choppy trade, though has been contained by key moving averages/VWAP levels, crude is mixed, and Treasuries have bull-flattened further. In fact, it was telling that as the short-end of the curve saw yields drop, USDJPY remained quite stable. The risk environement will no doubt be tested more forcefully over the course of the week, with a huge amount of Fedspeak, supply, ongoing trade talks, and the ominous inversion of the yield curve.

analysis_details: Oil prices traded rather choppy to kick off the week, with WTI little changed on settlement amidst a combination of bullish and bearish talking points. The market also remains cognizant of weak PMIs released Friday, despite a decent Ifo survey out of Germany today, which showed the first increase in six months. In supply news flow: South Korea and the US are to discuss extensions of Iranian sanction waivers this week; Exxon Baytown Texas refinery (584k BPD) plans to restart its large crude unit this week. Elsewhere, Positioning data of the week till March 19th showed hedge funds buying an additional 65mln bbls of oil futures and options, with net buyers of WTI, Brent and US gasoline, a firm bullish indication; this one week increase in net longs is the largest since the end of August 2018.

subject: UK Cabinet Office Minister Lidington says a further extension possibility is dependent on what parliament decides to do this week on Brexit
(UPDATE) BREXIT ANALYSIS: What is happening next?
content:
*MONDAY: MPs will debate the next Brexit steps alongside a number of amendments (see below) 

Today’s Schedule:

  • 0900 GMT - Ministers have been invited to assess documents on the seven options for the potential indicative votes
  • 1000 GMT – Emergency Cabinet meeting
  • Lunch – PM May to hold talks with Labour leader Corbyn and DUP leader Foster
  • 1530 GMT – PM May to make a statement to the House of Commons on last week’s EU summit
  • 1700 GMT – House Speaker expected to select amendments ahead of parliamentary debate on government’s next steps for Brexit
  • 1845 GMT – PM May (supposedly) to meet remain-leaning Government ministers - see source here
  • 2200 GMT – Voting begins on amendments

N.B. 1 - talkRADIO's Political Editor Kempsell highlights that the 1530 GMT speech by PM May is important as threats of indicative votes alone is not enough to move deal blockers in next 24 hours. Therefore how PM May clarifies her future may influence the DUP and ERG to fold

Amendments selected on Monday:

  • (A)   LETWIN: Seeks to change the rules of parliament on March 27 in order to provide time for lawmakers to debate and hold indicative votes. It has been signed by more than 120 lawmakers. The result of any such indicative votes would not be binding on the government but if it showed a majority for an alternative Brexit path. A similar amendment voted on earlier this month lost by two votes, this is therefore expected to have a good chance of passing.
  • (D)   LABOUR: Calls on the government to provide parliamentary time for lawmakers to find a majority for a different approach on Brexit.
  • (F)    BECKETT: This amendment states that if the UK comes within seven calendar days of leaving the EU without a deal, the government must ask parliament whether it would approve a no deal exit or if it should seek a further delay to Brexit
  • N.B. 2 -  Letwin amendment (A) will be whipped against tonight by the government, according to FT's Whitehall Correspondent Sebastian Payne citing Cabinet sources; Labour leader Corbyn said it will be supporting the amendment however.

Recent Rhetoric 

  • DUP has not shifted its position following the call between UK PM May and DUP leader Foster, reported via BBC's Political Editor Kuenssberg
  • Senior MPs reportedly expect Letwin amendment (A) to pass this evening, according to according to Business Insider's Senior Political Editor Payne. Furthermore, sources stated that it looks like amendment A will be passed in parliament but it is unclear whether or not it refers to the amendment being selected or approved in Parliament. If it was referring to approval, sources may lack as much credibility as the decision would be based on the votes of 650 Parliamentarians and therefore it is difficult for sources to represent the views of all MPs
  • Labour leader Corbyn told PM May there was no basis to bring her deal back to parliament a third time, according to a Labour party spokesman
  • Many ERG MPs ready to back PM May's deal tomorrow if she sets timetable for her departure, according to FT's Political Editor Parker
  • EU has warned that it is increasingly likely that the UK will leave the EU without a deal on April 12th

 

*TUESDAY: This had been penciled in as the potential date for MV3, however, May has pulled the vote for the time-being, citing a lack of Parliamentary support

N.B. 3 - UK PM May spokesman noted that the government will only hold another meaningful vote if there is prospect of success, and added that the government understands that there is no necessity to have a Brexit vote before March 29th after EU summit

*WEDNESDAY: UK PM May says parliament will debate secondary legislation to change the Brexit date in law on Wedneday.

*THURSDAY: Originally was seen as an alternative date for MV3 if the vote was not put before the HoC on Tuesday (note, this was before MV3 on Tuesday was pulled) 

*FRIDAY: Original Brexit date, earliest that will now happen is on April 12th

content: On Monday Apple (AAPL) is widely expected to unveil its video streaming service that places the tech giant in direct competition with market leader Netflix (NFLX). Pricing is not yet known; A USD 9.99/month Apple News Service will also likely be announced, another branch out into the media sector; but not all news sites are on board as Apple wants 50% of all subscription revenue. Magazine publishers, however, are embracing Apple's plan, MacRumors reported. Following the announcement of new iPads, iMacs and AirPods in the weeks running up to the event, it is unlikely any new hardware will be announced, although new Apple Pay features are expected to be unveiled, including partnerships for a credit scheme with Goldman Sachs.  Analysts at JPMorgan expect the event to lack any “catalyst” in regard to influence on the share price, where they cite pre-announced products and pre-set expectations taking away the chances of any surprises.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: risk back on, or rather not as averse, MV3 highly unlikely to go ahead on Tuesday
content:
DXY

The broad Dollar has traded mostly on the back foot within a 96.686-404 range in DXY terms, and technically the near term outlook remains bearish for the index while under the 30 DMA (96.632). Moreover, Barclays preliminary month end rebalancing model suggests a modest to moderate Usd short requirement vs the Eur, Jpy, Gbp, Cad and Aud.

AUD/NZD 

Coincidentally, the Aussie is emerging from a volatile Monday session as one of the G10 outperformers and back on the 0.7100 handle vs the Usd. However, the Aud is marginally lagging behind its Antipodean peer as the Kiwi revisits 0.6900 against its US counterpart and Aud/Nzd loses grip of 1.0300 again ahead of the RBNZ on Wednesday. More immediately, RBA’s Ellis is due to speak later tonight and could provide some independent impetus for the Aud.

SEK/NOK

The Swedish Krona is on track to be crowned champion currency in Scandinavia (and not far behind the Nzd in the major ranks) as a combination of bullish factors (chart signals, improving risk sentiment overall and an upbeat/hawkish Riksbank) aid a significant rebound from last Friday’s lows. Eur/Sek is hovering just shy of 10.4500 vs a more static Eur/Nok around 9.6685 amidst softer oil prices for the main part.

EUR

The single currency has gradually extended gains vs the Greenback to 1.1330 in wake of the latest German Ifo survey that painted a much better, or nowhere near as bad picture of the Eurozone’s premier economy compared to last Friday’s flash PMIs. The headline pair has now breached the 30 DMA at 1.1321 and could target 1.1350 next given no big chart hurdles in between.

GBP

The Pound has been very volatile either side of the 1.3200 marker vs the Usd and from 0.8600 to 0.8550 during EU trade vs the Euro, with Brexit still to the fore and the main driver. Attention remains on MV3, indicative votes and latest amendments after UK PM May held crisis meetings at her country estate over the weekend and only just overcame a Cabinet coup to oust her. She held more talks with her Ministers today, had a phone discussion with DUP leader Foster and spoke to opposition Labour leader Corbyn and it seemed that a 3rd vote on the WA could have been slated for Tuesday, but in a formal a statement she conceded there is still not enough support to bring it back to Parliament and will instead continue to talk with aim of holding another HoC vote this week. Note, big expiry options could have entered the fray in Cable, but 1.6 bn at the 1.3200 strike and 1.4 bn at 1.3250 were ultimately left unscathed.

JPY/CHF

Mixed fortunes for the renowned safe-haven currencies as Usd/Jpy rebounded from overnight lows alongside broad risk appetite and was there or thereabouts to trigger 2 bn expiries at 110.00 around the NY cut within a 109.72-110.23 range. However, the Franc benefited from general Usd weakness to trade at fresh peaks just above 0.9920 and stayed mid-range vs the Euro (1.1255-20).

 

CAD 

A late EU squeeze in crude that saw WTI trade flat vs circa Usd1/brl adrift at worst helped the Loonie rebound relatively firmly to circa 1.3400 vs its US rival from 1.3445 at the other extreme.

EM 

The Try has recaptured some of its recent outsize losses, but not without more pressure and selling during a whippy start to the week, and a big lift from the Buck’s broad downturn. Indeed, Lira woes look far from over despite more supportive rhetoric from the Government and CBRT, as some forward money market rates spiked to 29%. Usd/Try now around 5.5600 vs 5.7700+ at the high.

  • Viacom (VIAB), AT&T (T) – The two telecoms co.s were reportedly still in negotiations on Sunday evening to find a licensing agreement, before coming to an agreement on Monday morning

25th March 2019

DJIA

  • 3M (MMM), Honeywell (HON) – Deutsche Bank has made a “Catalyst Call” to sell 3M and move into Honeywell, citing Honeywell’s “attractive exposure” to late-cycle end markets. (Newswires)
  • Apple (AAPL) – The tech giant has had its price target raised to USD 220 from USD 189 at BTIG, citing expectations of a return to growth in 2020. CEO Tim Cook has publicly urged China to open up to the US, saying the future relies on collaboration between the two countries. Elsewhere, the co.’s planned gaming subscription will reportedly only include paid games, rather than “freemium” games, in which it will compensate developers depending on user play-time. Ahead of its special event on Monday, CNBC reports that the pricing details of its anticipated streaming service are not known even by its partners. (CNBC)

The co. has been awarded a USD 4.14bln Missile Defence Agency contract, for the delivery of a new missile field with 20 silos and two additional ones in a previous field constructed in Alaska. Elsewhere, US lawmakers are urging for either Boeing or FAA whistleblowers to provide any information in regard to the FAA’s approach of certifying 737 MAX jets; NY Times reported that the co. rushed to produce the jets in its race against competitor Airbus (AIR FP). subject: BAML positive on Apple (AAPL) iPhone order trends
content:
• Says following its upgrade of shares of Apple (AAPL) two weeks ago, the bank visited several suppliers in Asia last week, "and walked away comfortable that order trends have stabilized."

subject: Vale has been informed of halting operations at several tailing dams, adding that Brucutu mine (its largest iron ore complex in the state of Minas Gerais) will be the only mine to be affected and will not come back online as quickly as expected
Nomura quants say some bearish participants may have used 3m/10y inversion as excuse to sell, or take profits
content:
• Nomura says that on Friday, fundamentals-based global macro HFs added short positions on US stocks. "They have exhibited contrarian selling, which has dragged down the US stock market since it touched its highest level since last October, and thus we cannot rule that some bearish participants may have used the inversion of the 3m10y curve as an excuse to sell or take profits."
  • Nomura explains that some CTAs/systematic trend-followers were one forced to sell futures in response to an unexpected end to the upward trend in the US stock market, even though they were just about to resume buying futures. "The accumulated size of CTAs' long positions is estimated by Nomura to be relatively small, and the current tipping point or breakeven level for their long positions is ~2,750. So most of them have not felt it necessary to cut their loss-making positions so far," and the bank believes that "we are still far away from a situation where we need to be wary of mechanical liquidation caused by deleveraging by CTAs. "Trend-following programs have turned and suggest taking a 'waitand- see' approach or trying to sell futures slightly."
  • Nomura says that because of the inversion of the 3m10y curve we should be aware of changes in participants' behaviour. "In particular, we will monitor investors’ opinion, not economists, who have been relatively bullish on US stocks, relying on the steeping of the 5y30y curve since the beginning of the year." The bank says that if US equity market sentiment softens to near the neutral level, risk-taking appetite for medium and long-term investors will not be reduced. "A correction in stock prices should give them a good opportunity to buy on dips, and in particular, hopes of a US-China trade agreement and the 'Powell-put' (where the Fed may change the course of interest rates in response to volatility) have been major drivers of the risk rally since February."
  • The bank adds that accumulated money flows via ETFs in the US market continue to suggest re-allocation from government bonds to stocks as of 22 March. "Furthermore, unlike last December, the inversion of the UST curve has clearly not triggered massive underperformance in the cyclical sectors compared with the defensive sectors in US and global equity markets," and although the stock price index has moved sharply, "there has not been a shift in sector allocation that has priced in a US economic recession so far; rather, in contrast with the bond and rates markets, the stock market, on the surface, barely has expectations of a bottoming out of the US and global economies."

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 25th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%] are lower but edging towards positive territory, as risk sentiment recovers
  • US AG Barr’s summary of the Mueller Report stated that President Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia during the 2016 election but stopped short of exoneration
  • In FX markets, DXY resides within a tight range whilst GBP is tentative ahead of another crucial week for Brexit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include NZ trade balance, BoJ Summary of opinions

 

ASIA  

Asian equity markets began the week with hefty losses as the region followed suit to the stock sell-off last Friday on Wall St where disappointing PMI data from both sides of the Atlantic added to slowdown concerns, while curve inversion in which yields on US 3-month T-bills rose above 10yr yields for the first time since the GFC also stoked recession fears. ASX 200 (-1.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-3.1%) declined from the open in which Tech and Energy led the broad losses across the sectors in Australia, while selling in Tokyo was exacerbated by flows into JPY which dragged the local benchmark below the 21,000 level. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-2.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.9%) conformed to the negative tone as participants digested a slew of earnings and after PBoC inaction resulted to a CNY 60bln liquidity drain, with oil names among the worst hit following a recent slip in crude prices. Finally, 10yr JGBs were underpinned by safe-haven demand and as yields tracked the declines in global counterparts to push the 10yr JGB yield to its lowest since September 2016 and 30yr JGB yields to its lowest since November 2016. 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 60bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7098 (Prev. 6.6944)

BoJ's Harada states that the biggest contribution to Japan's economy from QQE was to boost productivity, and without it the jobless rate would not have fallen below 2.5%. (Newswires)

US is said to note that China’s initial offer regarding digital trade was not sufficient, according to the FT. Elsewhere, there were separate reports that President Trump dispatched a US Envoy to Germany to keep the pressure on Huawei, while Chinese Vice Premier Liu He is to travel to Washington on April 3rd following a visit by US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Trade Representative Lighthizer to Beijing set for this week. (Newswires/FT)

US

Attorney General William Barr submitted to Congress his summary of the main conclusions from special counsel Mueller’s investigation in which it found that President Trump's campaign did not collude with Russia during the 2016 election. Furthermore, the report summary did not draw a conclusion as to whether President Trump illegally obstructed justice but also did not exonerate him, while House Speaker Pelosi and Senate Minority Leader Schumer suggested that William Barr is not a neutral observer of the Mueller report and said Congress require full Mueller report and underlying documents. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (voter, dove) said the US economy is in a strong position and that it is a good time to pause and be cautious, while he added that US monetary policy is currently neither accommodative or restrictive. Evans also commented they will take action if inflation undershoots, while he wants to see more inflation and does not expect a rate hike till H2 next year. Adding they may have to ease if exonomic activity weakens more than expected and that the recent US data has been softer than expected. (Newswires)

Fed’s Harker (non-voter, dove) says economic risks tilt very slightly to the downside, and that outlook is pretty good. He reiterated the Fed’s wait-and-see stance whilst stating he favours one rate hike at most this year. He noted inflation is around the Fed's target, is edging slightly downward. Finally, he expects GDP slightly above 2% in 2019, returning to around 2% trend level in 2020. (Newswires)

UK/EU   

* For reference a full list of amendments along with an indicative timetable for today & this week is available on the headline feed.

Reports suggested on Sunday UK PM May could reportedly be ousted in days as her cabinet plot to replace her with Michael Gove as caretaker PM, while a senior Downing Street source stated PM May’s Chief Whip has advised her to set out her departure plans and some ministers are predicting she could be gone in 10 days. There were also reports that 11 Cabinet Ministers confirmed they want to replace PM May with her Deputy Liddington, while UK Chancellor Hammond commented the UK must find a way to leave the EU but replacing PM May will not help. (Daily Mail/The Sun) PM May was reportedly told at yesterday’s Chequers’ meeting that she must set out a timetable to leave her premiership in order to get her deal through Parliament; according to Buzzfeed reporter. (Buzzfeed) Late on Sunday, reports stated that May has resisted pressure to set a date for her departure in return for support for her EU divorce deal after a threatened cabinet coup fizzled out. The report stated that instead the PM will allow Parliament to move towards adopting a softer exit from the EU in order to force the hand of Brexiteers to support her deal. (Times)

UK PM May said on Friday it is possible the UK could request a new A50 extension if her deal is rejected, while she also suggested that she might not bring her MV3 back to parliament this week if it is likely to fail. In related news, PM May is expected to unveil plans to hold indicative votes and is considering offering votes regarding the Brexit deal, no-deal, 2nd referendum, revoking Article 50, FTA customs union and the single market according to Telegraph’s political reporter. (Newswires/BBC/Telegraph) Ministers have been invited to assess documents on the seven options for the potential indicative votes at 0900GMT today; according to Telegraph’s Deputy Political Editor Swinford (Twitter) PM May is expected to hold a cabinet meeting at 1000GMT to update ministers on her Brexit strategy. (BBC News)

The Sun newspaper editorial stated UK PM May should announce on Monday that she will stand down once her Brexit deal is approved and UK leaves the EU. (The Sun)

Minutes from a meeting of EU ambassadors and senior officials stated that European Commission Secretary General Selmayr asked colleagues to imagine scenarios featuring a new Brexit secretary or new Prime Minister in which the starting point in such a scenario must not be a renegotiation of the UK’s withdrawal from the EU, while Selmayr added that Article 50 has been agreed and the process is over. (The Observer)

UK PM May will reportedly quit if Boris Johnson, Iain Duncan Smith, Steven Baker, Jacob Rees-Mogg and David Davis vote for her deal, however she gave no specifics so there is not much trust she will actually quit; according to ITV's Peston. (Twitter)

UK Tory lawmaker Evans notes that several lawmakers want an orderly replacement of UK PM May after she gets her deal through Parliament. (Newswires)

Reading room on Brexit indicative votes this morning for UK cabinet ministers was pulled, however this is unclear what it means for both indicative votes and Meaningful Vote 3. Cabinet is now underway; according to Telegraph's Swinford. (Twitter)

Senior UK MPs expect the Letwin (A) amendment to pass this evening, adding that what the government is offering on indicative votes does not go far enough, according to Business Insider's Senior Political Editor Payne. (Newswires)

  • German Ifo Business Climate (Mar) 99.6 vs. Exp. 98.5 (Prev. 98.5, Rev. 98.7)
  • German Ifo Current Conditions (Mar) 103.8 vs. Exp. 102.9 (Prev. 103.4, Rev. 103.6)
  • German Ifo Expectations (Mar) 95.6 vs. Exp. 94 (Prev. 93.8, Rev. 94)

 

ECB's Rehn (Neutral) said Brexit is the biggest threat to Euro zone in the short-term and that markets are underestimating the risks, while he added Euro zone growth has slowed significantly and that we must be concerned. (Newswires)

ECB's Hansson (Hawk) says that the Euro-area slowdown may continue in the medium term; tiered deposit rate has not really been discussed. QE could be restarted in event of major shock. (Newswires)

S&P affirmed Belgium at AA; Outlook Stable, affirmed Spain at A-; Outlook Stable and affirmed Norway at AAA; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Reports of a explosion at a US Military Base in Okinawa on Sunday, report indicates that no one was injured in the explosion. (Sputnik)

EQUITIES

European equities kicked off Monday trade mostly lower [Stoxx 600 -0.2%] following a dismal lead from Asia wherein the Nikkei 225 shed 3.0% and closed below 21,000 for the first time in over a month. Back in Europe, stocks have somewhat nursed opening losses as sentiment improved following a better-than-forecast German Ifo Survey which aided the DAX (+0.1%) climb into positive territory. Elsewhere, Italy’s FTSE MIB (+0.4%) is marginally outperforming its peers as Fiat Chrysler (+3.3%) supports the index amid reports its chairman is pushing for a tie up with a rival, Peugeot (-0.7%) has been touted as a potential suitor. Sector-wise, IT names are underperforming, in-fitting with the sector’s performance overnight, whilst the consumer discretionary sector is buoyed by the overall positivity in auto stocks. Finally, this morning saw a LVMH (-0.5%) open lower by just under 9% and immediately pared losses with traders citing a potential “fat-finger” incident.

FX

EUR - Not the biggest G10 mover or best performer, but the single currency has staged a firmer recovery rebound from sub-1.1300 lows vs the Dollar in wake of an encouraging Ifo survey, with beats on all 3 key metrics compounded by upward revisions to the previous month across the board. Hot on the heels of last Friday’s dire Eurozone preliminary PMIs, and an especially worrying German manufacturing print, the institute contends that the bloc’s number one economy is displaying relative resistance, and this has helped to dispel some concerns about a deeper slowdown, or even recession. However, Eur/Usd has not clearly breached upside technical resistance in the form of the 30 DMA that comes in around 1.1321.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns are back on the front foot and leading the major league, with the Sek especially buoyant on a mixture of improving risk sentiment, bullish technicals and the Riksbank maintaining repo rate guidance for further tightening. Eur/Sek is back down below 10.4500 and Eur/Nok is eying bids/support at 9.6500 against the backdrop of oil prices trying to recover some poise after their end of week rout.

AUD/NZD/CAD - All firmer vs their US counterpart after sharp underperformance last Friday when aversion was rife and safe-haven positioning escalated. Aud/Usd is back within striking distance of 0.7100 and Nzd/Usd is not too much further from 0.6900 even though Aud/Nzd has crossed 1.0300 from its latest decline through the big figure, while Usd/Cad is hovering near the bottom end of a 1.3445-05 range, as the Loonie also derives some underlying support from the aforementioned bounce in crude.

JPY/GBP/CHF - Usd/Jpy has bounced from overnight safe-haven lows in line with the gradual improvement in risk appetite and through heavy 110.00 option expiry interest at the round number (2 bn), while Cable also looks unlikely to test expiry interest or hedges at the 1.3200 strike (1.6 bn) given ongoing/heightened Brexit jitters that have pulled the Pound down towards 1.3160 and close to 0.8600 vs the Euro (Ifo also impacting this pair). Similarly, the Franc has unwound some safe-haven premium towards 0.9950 against the Greenback from circa 0.9933 at one stage and 1.1250 vs around 1.1223 against the single currency.

EM - Yet more thrills and spills for the Lira after official intervention against a big US bank that put out a bearish trade recommendation on the Try, and the CBRT’s decision to double swap limits on outstanding FX maturities after shelving 1 week repos. Usd/Try currently at 5.6400 within a 5.7700-5.5700 band.

Turkish President Erdogan said those in the finance sector that purchase foreign currencies on expectations a decline in TRY, will pay a very heavy price. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

In stark contrast to Friday’s almost universally dire PMIs, the March Ifo survey revealed a clean sweep of beats vs consensus and upgrades to back month readings for all 3 metrics, but the market reaction has been relatively limited. Nevertheless, Bunds have retreated further from earlier peaks to a 165.34 base, and the corresponding 10 year yield has crossed parity, albeit just, with Gilts down to 128.82 in sympathy. Meanwhile, having resisted the bulk of the bearish impulses from EU counterparts Treasuries have caved in; with the curve bear-steepening after Friday’s extreme flattening and yield compression. Indeed, 3-month 10yr spread is back to norm following its inversion.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.1%) and Brent (-0.1%) futures have rebounded off lows amid an improvement in risk-appetite with the former flirting with the USD 59.00/bbl to the upside whilst the latter resides just below the USD 67.00/bbl level. The latest CFTC data also shows that speculators increased next longs in NYMEX WTI by over 54k lots with a bulk of this increase driven by fresh positions. Elsewhere, Chinese crude imports increased by 2% in February to average around 10.3mln BPD, with a Y/Y increase of just under 22%. Furthermore, the country increased its share of Iranian and Venezuelan imports over February.

Metals are largely on the front foot with gold (+0.4%) gaining further ground above USD 1300/oz with the recent fears surrounding and inverted yield curve between the US front-end and 10yr (Note: this has reversed) prompting additional demand in the yellow metal. Elsewhere, the twin cyclones which hit Australia over the weekend impacted mining and energy operations in the region, with reports stating some activities have been halted at BHP and Rio Tinto’s Pilbara mine. The mine is located in Western Australia and accounts for almost 40% of global iron ore production. The storms have now weakened to a category two, however there is no clarity on how long production will be halted and of any potential costs to the Australian economy.

US Coast Guard announced Houston Ship Channel closure impacting a 2-mile span and didn’t provide a timeline for reopening. (Newswires)

China's Feb crude oil imports Y/Y: from Iran 509,711 BPD +7.4%; from Russia 1.498mln BPD +13.6%; from US 22,380 BPD -91%; from Saudi Arabia 1.552mln BPD +28.5%; from Venezuela 530,148 +98%. (Newswires)

subject: ANALYSIS: Treasury 3m/10y inversion stoking fears of recession
content:
• Given the 3m/10y spread inverted on Friday for the first time since 2007 (and has been meandering in and out of inversion since then, currently around 1.5bps), there has been heightened attention on its implications, and specifically, what it portends for the future performance of the US economy, given that the 3m/10y part of the curve inverted aead of recessions in 2007/09, 2001, and the 1990/1 recession; it also inverted in 1998 slightly, and at the end of 1995 though the economy continued to grow.  
  • Traders have been passing around the SF Fed's analysis on yield curve spreads, penned last August, which concluded that "the traditional 10y–3m spread is the most reliable predictor (of recession), and we do not find any evidence that would support discarding this long-standing benchmark as a measure of the shape of the yield curve. It is worth emphasizing again, however, that all of these term spreads are fairly accurate predictors and quite informative about future recession risk." The SF followd-up with an analysis in February, where it said the shape of the curve was "worrisome," but concluded then that it needed to see a clear inversion of the curve, and it was too early to predict a recession then.
  • SocGen's strategists think that we will see a US recession in 2020, in what it descrives as "a hangover that will follow the excesses of the fiscal package and the damage done by US trade policy." But that view is not consensus; ING does not see a US recession either this year or next given the still solid US economy. "Rather, we view the trend of global curve flattening as natural at the current stage of the cycle, in line with a gradual economic slowdown rather than pencilling an imminent recession."

subject: RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Sentiment lifted as German Ifo beats forecasts amidst more Brexit angst  - 25th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities kicked off Monday trade mostly lower [Stoxx 600 -0.2%] following a dismal lead from Asia wherein the Nikkei 225 shed 3.0% and closed below 21,000 for the first time in over a month. Back in Europe, stocks have somewhat nursed opening losses as sentiment improved following a better-than-forecast German Ifo Survey which aided the DAX (Unch) to briefly climb into positive territory. Elsewhere, Italy’s FTSE MIB (+0.5%) is marginally outperforming its peers as Fiat Chrysler (+3.0%) supports the index amid reports its chairman is pushing for a tie up with a rival, Peugeot (-0.7%) has been touted as a potential suitor. Sector-wise, IT names are underperforming, in-fitting with the sector’s performance overnight, whilst the consumer discretionary sector is buoyed by the overall positivity in auto stocks. Finally, this morning saw a LVMH (+0.4%) open lower by just under 9% and immediately pared losses with traders citing a potential “fat-finger” incident.

FX

EUR - Not the biggest G10 mover or best performer, but the single currency has staged a firmer recovery rebound from sub-1.1300 lows vs the Dollar in wake of an encouraging Ifo survey, with beats on all 3 key metrics compounded by upward revisions to the previous month across the board. Hot on the heels of last Friday’s dire Eurozone preliminary PMIs, and an especially worrying German manufacturing print, the institute contends that the bloc’s number one economy is displaying relative resistance, and this has helped to dispel some concerns about a deeper slowdown, or even recession. However, Eur/Usd has not clearly breached upside technical resistance in the form of the 30 DMA that comes in around 1.1321.

SEK/NOK - The Scandi Crowns are back on the front foot and leading the major league, with the Sek especially buoyant on a mixture of improving risk sentiment, bullish technicals and the Riksbank maintaining repo rate guidance for further tightening. Eur/Sek is back down below 10.4500 and Eur/Nok is eying bids/support at 9.6500 against the backdrop of oil prices trying to recover some poise after their end of week rout.

AUD/NZD/CAD - All firmer vs their US counterpart after sharp underperformance last Friday when aversion was rife and safe-haven positioning escalated. Aud/Usd is back within striking distance of 0.7100 and Nzd/Usd is not too much further from 0.6900 even though Aud/Nzd has crossed 1.0300 from its latest decline through the big figure, while Usd/Cad is hovering near the bottom end of a 1.3445-05 range, as the Loonie also derives some underlying support from the aforementioned bounce in crude.

JPY/GBP/CHF - Usd/Jpy has bounced from overnight safe-haven lows in line with the gradual improvement in risk appetite and through heavy 110.00 option expiry interest at the round number (2 bn), while Cable also looks unlikely to test expiry interest or hedges at the 1.3200 strike (1.6 bn) given ongoing/heightened Brexit jitters that have pulled the Pound down towards 1.3160 and close to 0.8600 vs the Euro (Ifo also impacting this pair). Similarly, the Franc has unwound some safe-haven premium towards 0.9950 against the Greenback from circa 0.9933 at one stage and 1.1250 vs around 1.1223 against the single currency.

EM - Yet more thrills and spills for the Lira after official intervention against a big US bank that put out a bearish trade recommendation on the Try, and the CBRT’s decision to double swap limits on outstanding FX maturities after shelving 1 week repos. Usd/Try currently at 5.6400 within a 5.7700-5.5700 band.

FIXED INCOME

In stark contrast to Friday’s almost universally dire PMIs, the March Ifo survey revealed a clean sweep of beats vs consensus and upgrades to back month readings for all 3 metrics, but the market reaction has been relatively limited. Nevertheless, Bunds have retreated further from earlier peaks to a 165.34 base, and the corresponding 10 year yield has crossed parity, albeit just, with Gilts down to 128.82 in sympathy.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.1%) and Brent (-0.1%) futures have rebounded off lows amid an improvement in risk-appetite with the former flirting with the USD 59.00/bbl to the upside whilst the latter resides just below the USD 67.00/bbl level. The latest CFTC data also shows that speculators increased next longs in NYMEX WTI by over 54k lots with a bulk of this increase driven by fresh positions. Elsewhere, Chinese crude imports increased by 2% in February to average around 10.3mln BPD, with a Y/Y increase of just under 22%. Furthermore, the country increased its share of Iranian and Venezuelan imports over February.

Metals are largely on the front foot with gold (+0.4%) gaining further ground above USD 1300/oz with the recent fears surrounding and inverted yield curve between the US front-end and 10yr (Note: this has reversed) prompting additional demand in the yellow metal. Elsewhere, the twin cyclones which hit Australia over the weekend impacted mining and energy operations in the region, with reports stating some activities have been halted at BHP and Rio Tinto’s Pilbara mine. The mine is located in Western Australia and accounts for almost 40% of global iron ore production. The storms have now weakened to a category two, however there is no clarity on how long production will be halted and of any potential costs to the Australian economy.

Pantheon Macroeconomics writes on the German IFO data release:
content: The data will have provided some relief, after dreadful PMIs on Friday, with the headline surprising to the upside, driven by the expectations component rising to a three-month high. The details, however, chime with the PMI data, Pantheon Macroeconomics said: "the headline manufacturing sentiment index slid further, while confidence in services, construction and wholesale trade rose," adding that "overall, the IFO continues to signal a further slowdown in GDP growth in Q1, but the headlines confirm the story that manufacturing is in the grips of a recession, while the rest of the economy is stabilising, or even improving slightly, towards the end of Q1

content: • Click here for the tweet
analysis_details: (A)   LETWIN: Seeks to change the rules of parliament on March 27 in order to provide time for lawmakers to debate and hold indicative votes. It has been signed by more than 120 lawmakers. The result of any such indicative votes would not be binding on the government but if it showed a majority for an alternative Brexit path. A similar amendment voted on earlier this month lost by two votes, this is therefore expected to have a good chance of passing.

subject: UK debt on the back foot, STIR futures all over the place
content: A very lively return to Liffe amidst breaking Brexit headlines ahead of key Governmental meetings to discuss indicative votes and how to proceed with MV3 following the weekend Cabinet showdown and a Cabinet coup against PM May that she only just survived. Gilts gapped down 14 ticks to 129.08 and have traded lower since within a 128.90-129.12 range alongside retreating Bunds, and US Treasuries to a lesser degree, as reports emerge that the PM did offer to resign, albeit not mentioning any timeframe, in an effort (last ditch) to secure enough support for the WA. However, the Short Sterling strip has been much more indecisive and volatile either side of parity between +1.5 to -1 tick at the extremes, trying to weigh up all options including the PM’s deal, no deal, a softer and even A 50 being revoked completely. All eyes/ears now on the 9.00GMT and 10.00GMT meetings ahead of what promises to be yet another dramatic if not climactic week in Parliament.

content: It remains to be seen whether the 10 year German benchmark and Eurozone debt peers are merely refuelling before another charge higher, but for the time being more safe-haven and PMI inspired gains are eroding eyeing the EU cash equity opens and in advance of the latest Ifo survey. Bunds just slipped to a fresh Eurex low at 165.45 having climbed just above last Friday’s 165.74 close to 165.76 at one stage, while losses elsewhere are also building as bonds take stock and brace for further direction. Also ahead, several ECB speakers including Coeure, Costa and Lautenenschlager.

Scout24 (G24 GY) - Following the Pulver Bidco takeover offer, boards will refrain from convening the 2019 AGM. (Newswires)

Salini Impregilo (SAL IM) – Co. have been awarded a USD 524mln contract to build a Caloosahatchee Basin in South Florida, to be completed in 2024. (Newswires)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – EC has approved Forxiga for the use in Type 1 Diabetes as an adjunct to insulin patients who have a BMT equal to/above 27. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Boeing (BA) plans to meet with customers and regulators this week to explains plans to get its 737 Max back into service following the two disasters in under five months. (Newswires)

Provident Financial (PFG LN) – Non-Standard Finance (NSF LN) has urged Co. board to accept its offer without delay whilst outlining Co’s failure to develop a decisive plan regarding its problems. (Newswires)

Inmarsat (ISAT LN) – Co. and Triton Bidco have reached an agreement of a recommended cash offer for the Co. of around USD 3.4bln. Co. shareholders who are entitled to receive a final dividend will be entitled to receive USD 7.21 per share. Offer is part of a joint venture involving Apax, Warburg Pincus & CPPIB. Co’s directors say they consider the acquisitions terms to be both fair and reasonable; and the acquisition is expected to become effective in Q4 2019. (Newswires)

Ahold Delhaize (AD NA) – Co. says no impact is expected on funding structure, credit ratings and underlying outlook from IFRS 16 accounting change. (Newswires)

John Wood Group (WG. LN) – Co. disposes of non-core business for USD 38mln. (Newswires)

Sanofi (SAN FP) – Co’s diabetes drug has failed to win FDA approval. (Newswires) 

Metro Bank (MTRO LN) – Co. is said to be at risk of losing GBP 120mln of funding. (Newswires)

Societe Generale (GLE FP) – Moody’s states that the Co’s digitally-driven strategy in Africa will raise their growth and profit potential, although add that it will also increase risk. (Newswires)

Allianz (ALV GY), Generali (G IM) – Co.’s are to reportedly bid for BBVA’s (BBVA SM) insurance assets. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – Co. reputedly cancelled 22 flights today due to software problems. (Newswires)

Schneider Electric (SU FP) – Co. have entered into exclusive negotiations with Transom Capital concerning the sale of their Pelco Business unit, which had revenues of EUR 169mln in 2017. (Newswires)

Pennon (PNN LN) – Co. state that FY18/19 underlying financial performance was in-line with expectations. Co. state that following Interserve entering administration they are seeking further clarification over the financial position of Interserve Construction Limited. (Newswires)

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

25th March 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week with hefty losses as the region followed suit to the stock sell-off last Friday on Wall St where disappointing PMI data from both sides of the Atlantic added to slowdown concerns, while curve inversion in which yields on US 3-month T-bills rose above 10yr yields for the first time since the GFC also stoked recession fears. ASX 200 (-1.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-3.1%) declined from the open in which Tech and Energy led the broad losses across the sectors in Australia, while selling in Tokyo was exacerbated by flows into JPY which dragged the local benchmark below the 21,000 level. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) conformed to the negative tone as participants digested a slew of earnings and after PBoC inaction resulted to a CNY 60bln liquidity drain, with oil names among the worst hit following a recent slip in crude prices.

FTSE

GVC Holdings (GVC LN) – Co’s Chairman, Lee Feldman, is close to leaving following new rules limiting a Chairman’s term to 9 years; after the chairman recently sold shares alongside the Chief Executive which totalled nearly GBP 20mln. (CityAM/Sky)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – Co. has declined to rule out acquiring one of the Big Six energy suppliers [British Gas (CNA LN), EDF (EDF FP), E.ON (EOAN GY), npower (IGY GY), Scottish Power (IBE SM) and SSE (SSE LN)], as it said it will consider “all opportunities” to expand in the UK household gas and electricity supply market. (Times)

RBS (RBS LN) – Co. is reportedly facing pressure from small investors who are seeking more control over corporate governance. Co. will hold a vote at its annual meeting next month on whether to create a committee of shareholder representatives that would regularly meet with board members and executives. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

ConvaTec (CTEC LN) – Co. will announce a sweeping boardroom overhaul today which includes the departure of chairman Christopher Gent. (Sky News)

Merlin Properties (MRL SM) – Co. is said to be seeing to refinance around EUR 1.6bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – Co’s CEO states that the management team still has the supervisory boards support, following increased pressure on the Co. after a US Jury ruled that the Co’s Roundup weed killer caused cancer. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – CEO states the Co. are looking to produce electric vehicles in China for the local market and for export. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Co.’s top managers have been banned from selling shares while it explores a merger with Commerzbank (CBK GY). In related news, Deutsche Bank’s investment arm is said to be a focus of merger talks. Furthermore, employees from both banks are said to be jointly resisting a merger. (FT/Handelsblatt/Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Scout24 (G24 GY) – FY revenue EUR 531.7mln, +12.5%. Co. confirms record results for FY18 and expects group revenue to grow by between 15-17% in 2019. Board state they are confident they Co’s dynamic development will continue into 2019. Co. propose a FY dividend of EUR 0.64 per share. (Newswires)

Rheinmetall (RHM GY) – The Queensland government in Australia, reportedly backs the Co.’s circa AUD 15bln bid for the Land 400 contract. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

LVMH (MC FP) – Chief Executive of the Co’s Bulgari Brand reportedly wants their watch business to be in the top ten makers of Swiss watches. (Neue Zuercher Zeitung/Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Alstom (ALO FP) – African Development Bank Group stated that two General Electric (GE) subsidies, which were owned by Alstom until 2015, would be temporarily prevented from bidding on power contracts as they are found to have engaged in bribery and fraud in 2006 & 2011 (Newswires)
